bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Manuel Perez Beato, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench poses questions concerning the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Manuel Perez Beato, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
copy to Mrs Phillips
" " Moran (to show to Rojas)
Rojas to show Moran
August 26, ???
Dr. Manuel Perez Beato
San Marino
Kate #112
Vibora, Havana
Cuba
My dear Doctor Beato:
div1.p:
Do you remember in April of this year Senorita Maria Teresa
Rojas and her friend, Senorita Lydia Cabrerra, brought Mr. John Moran of Havana
and me around to call on you, to ask you for some data regarding the work of Dr.
Finlay and of Major Walter Reed and the U.S. Army in discovering the cause of
yellow fever. You were very kind to us. This October, the American college where
Dr. Lazear went to school, is dedicating a memorial building in his honor, and I
have been asked to make an address on the conquest of yellow fever. There are a
number of points about which I am anxious to have information, but have not yet
been able to get it. I understand that you are the official historian of the province
of Havana, and I am taking the liberty of writing to you asking if you can give me
some information or give me the name of someone who might be able to.
I am anxious to find out the following:

When was the Camp Columbia (made up of tents) erected, and what
was on the site before hand?

When was the tent Camp Columbia torn down and replaced by the
wooden Columbia Barracks?

When was the latter torn down and replaced by the present
Military City?

Do you know of any written history of Camp Columbia or Columbia
Barracks?

Do you know whether the history of Las Animas Hospital has ever
been written up?

Is there a historian or other official in the town of Marianao
that could find me an old map showing the locations of Camp Columbia and of the town
of Marianao as of 1900?

Is there a librarian in Havana or Marianao or some other official
or historian who might have old photographs of Columbia Barracks? and of Las Animas
Hospital, of the Maestranza and of Military Hospital #1 as of 1900?

Military Hospital No. 1 was used by U.S. Army during the Cuban
War, and was situated on Principe Hill overlooking the city of Havana. Here Dr. Agramonte
did some of his work. Am I correct that this was originally the hospital Alfonso XIII?
I am anxious to find some old photographs of this hospital and also to know exactly
where it was located. Mr. Moran thought that the Calixto Garcia Hospital was now on the
site.

I certainly appreciate whatever help you can give me. To save you
the labor of answering this by long hand, will you permit me to have Mrs. R. Hart
Phillips, Manzana de Gomez, 553, who does secretarial work, and meets you at your con-
venience, and type your answers for me. I shall be delighted to pay the charge. I shall
also be delighted to express my appreciation for your help when I publish my paper.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P.S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
